top_comments.author: @typicalnewenglander
top_comments.text:
Yesterday, outside of the EU, you could’ve bought a 14 for roughly the same price. You’d have gotten an extra camera, same functional design, and MagSafe. Today you get Apple intelligence, a much improved single camera, the best battery in the small form factor, USB-C and an Apple cellular modem… It’s a tough sell.

My first thought was “oh, this will fall to $499 in the fall when Apple does the annual slide.” Then I thought again. This was designed to replace the iPhone 15, not the SE or 14. It was convenient to discontinue them globally since they were already discontinued in other regions. As such, I’m currently thinking iPhone 15 will be discontinued in September, making the entire lineup compatible with Apple Intelligence. The “e” model could update annually. However, I could see it becoming biennial. This makes sense because the iPhone 16 would progress from 799 -> 699 -> 599. However, this device occupies the 599 slot. Meaning when iPhone 18 is released, we will likely get an 18e the following March with a design similar to that of the 16, if the design has shifted by then.

This is all just theory however. The point of the SE was to reuse old parts. This seems to use a bit of new and old to create a Frankenstein of sorts that is better and worse. Only time will tell. But I bet as soon as all flagship iPhones ship with 3 or more cameras, the “low end” will have 2 and will look a lot like the phones we have today.

top_comments.author: @barttfisher
top_comments.text: Achieving success hinges on the steps you actively take toward it. Accumulating wealth involves cultivating positive habits, such as consistently setting aside money at intervals for robust investments. top_comments.author: @CalmerThanYouAre1
top_comments.text:
As someone who’s been through a few crashes, downturns and corrections, it’s hands down SCHD for me if I had to pick only one. However I own SCHG and Fidelity’s version of VOO as well. 

The mental and emotional side of investing often get overlooked. Most of us have risk aversion and feel the pain of paper losses much more acutely than the bliss of paper gains. I think this is amplified when you have multiple seven figures of assets and a career’s worth of investments in play. Good luck sleeping well at night with QQQ when the next crash comes and you’re down 50%+!

top_comments.author: @Tomzzzzzz
top_comments.text:
If you had to have only one ETF, there is a strong case to be made for VIG over VOO. If you look at performance and risk since inception for VIG (June 2006) vs VOO (using VFINX as proxy since VOO data does not go back far enough), you will find that the total return of VFINX was only slightly higher, but volatility and max draw down were considerably worse (12% higher standard deviation and 24% larger max drawdown). Using Sharpe ratio for risk adjusted return, VIG also came in higher than VOO over that time period. 

In a way, VIG applies a "quality" factor screen on top of the S&P 500. VIG holds 314 companies in its portfolio so its broadly diversified. When looking at US Large Cap Blend style ETFs, I think VIG makes a very strong case for replacing VOO in portfolios where risk and volatility need to be minimized, while still offering quality returns and a better income stream than VOO. The ideal use case for VIG is retirees who are living off their accounts looking for lower volatility than the S&P 500, but still solid total returns and a larger income stream (since dividends would be consumed and not reinvested). 

SCHD is a possible alternative to VIG, but with less history so it's hard to say how much "better" it would be than VIG in the long run on a total return basis. Using historical data since inception for SCHD (Nov 2011) and with dividends NOT reinvested, VIG has had a slightly higher total return% through May 31, 2023 at lower volatility and lower max drawdown, although SCHD has provided significantly higher income over that timeframe. Unfortunately, so far in 2023 SCHD isn't faring well and is currently underperforming VIG by over 9% as a result of its reconstitution in March. SCHD also only holds 100 stocks, so its subject to more downside than a more diversified ETF like VIG.

Comparison Charts: 
(a) VIG vs SCHD vs VOO (2023 YTD): https://schrts.co/rYJYXmnv
(b) VIG vs SCHD vs VOO (2022-2023 YTD): https://schrts.co/qtQDZyMD

top_comments.author: @patrickfuchs3859
top_comments.text: Speaking as a trader, passive income from dividends pales in comparison to compounded trading gains. As a simple example, $100 compounded at 1% 5 times in two weeks times 26 periods results in an annual gain of 265%. Often a trader might only get .5% interest in a trade, but quite often a trader will get 3-7% in a trade. I have had many dividends over the years paying quite well, but I'll take compounded gains before going after dividends.

top_comments.author: @mjs28s
top_comments.text:
Your PRF numbers are still sus, even though you checked two sources.

@15:25

Your spreadsheet shows the dividend at $0.38 (rounded from $0.3763). That is NOT accounting for the 5:1 split. The adjusted dividend on 9/19/2014 is actually $0.0753.

I think that the dividend data is not adjusted for the 5:1 split while the share price data you got was. I ran PRF through portfolio visualizer and dont get even close to those income levels, dividends reinvested or not.

Your calculations have almost the entire history of PRF dividends at 5 times the rate that they actually were paid at.

The sudden drop that you speak of on the dividend yield is literally when the 5:1 split happened...in 2023. All the dividends on your table leading up to the one paid in June 2023 forward, all need to be divided by 5.

top_comments.author: @CaptainProx
top_comments.text:
While a lot of people are debunking the effectiveness of PRF, I think DGRO is the most well rounded Dividend ETF

Out of these ETFs it specializes a bit more into long term Capital Gain, but while it isn’t THE top for Capital Gain on this list, it has a considerably higher dividend income than almost all of the ETFs above it

It’s also worth noting that it specializes in Dividend GROWTH. It’s never missed a year of dividend growth or payment, and dividend growth is often considered the most important part of Dividend investing for most people.

I’ve chosen to pair DGRO with QQQ and SCHD

I prefer being an actual shareholder, though – – and owning ETFs does not make you a shareholder.

top_comments.author: @barttfisher
top_comments.text: Achieving success hinges on the steps you actively take toward it. Accumulating wealth involves cultivating positive habits, such as consistently setting aside money at intervals for robust investments. Financial management, often avoided by many, can later become a haunting issue. My hope is that anyone reading this finds success in their journey!

top_comments.author: @CalmerThanYouAre1
top_comments.text:
As someone who’s been through a few crashes, downturns and corrections, it’s hands down SCHD for me if I had to pick only one. However I own SCHG and Fidelity’s version of VOO as well. 

The mental and emotional side of investing often get overlooked. Most of us have risk aversion and feel the pain of paper losses much more acutely than the bliss of paper gains. I think this is amplified when you have multiple seven figures of assets and a career’s worth of investments in play. Good luck sleeping well at night with QQQ when the next crash comes and you’re down 50%+!

top_comments.author: @Tomzzzzzz
top_comments.text:
If you had to have only one ETF, there is a strong case to be made for VIG over VOO. If you look at performance and risk since inception for VIG (June 2006) vs VOO (using VFINX as proxy since VOO data does not go back far enough), you will find that the total return of VFINX was only slightly higher, but volatility and max draw down were considerably worse (12% higher standard deviation and 24% larger max drawdown). Using Sharpe ratio for risk adjusted return, VIG also came in higher than VOO over that time period. 

In a way, VIG applies a "quality" factor screen on top of the S&P 500. VIG holds 314 companies in its portfolio so its broadly diversified. When looking at US Large Cap Blend style ETFs, I think VIG makes a very strong case for replacing VOO in portfolios where risk and volatility need to be minimized, while still offering quality returns and a better income stream than VOO. The ideal use case for VIG is retirees who are living off their accounts looking for lower volatility than the S&P 500, but still solid total returns and a larger income stream (since dividends would be consumed and not reinvested). 

SCHD is a possible alternative to VIG, but with less history so it's hard to say how much "better" it would be than VIG in the long run on a total return basis. Using historical data since inception for SCHD (Nov 2011) and with dividends NOT reinvested, VIG has had a slightly higher total return% through May 31, 2023 at lower volatility and lower max drawdown, although SCHD has provided significantly higher income over that timeframe. Unfortunately, so far in 2023 SCHD isn't faring well and is currently underperforming VIG by over 9% as a result of its reconstitution in March. SCHD also only holds 100 stocks, so its subject to more downside than a more diversified ETF like VIG.

Comparison Charts: 
(a) VIG vs SCHD vs VOO (2023 YTD): https://schrts.co/rYJYXmnv
(b) VIG vs SCHD vs VOO (2022-2023 YTD): https://schrts.co/qtQDZyMD

top_comments.author: @williamrogers1219
top_comments.text: Equal-weighted means this fund is riskier than the S&P 500 ETF as it tilts towards smaller and value companies. RSP has a much higher standard deviation and higher worst years or max drawdowns resulting in a lower Sharpe Ratio than SPY. With Vanguard, the ETF is a separate share class of the mutual fund class. If you own VTI, you don't need to own S&P 500 or QQQ as all these companies are included in VTI. Sector funds are speculative bets and sectors are not one of the five dimensions of market returns. VIGI is the international dividend version of VIG. Semiconductor is not a sector, it is a sub-industry under the Technology sector.

top_comments.author: @byteme0000
top_comments.text:
DGRW is an intriguing ETF, but the dividends are low (1.94% as I type this), the payout amounts are inconsistent and not at all linear, and the expense ratio is about 4-1/2 times higher than SCHD. This ETF seems to be tough competitor to SCHD on the surface, but remember that the primary goal of a quality income ETF is steady and growing dividend payouts while maintaining (or preferably growing) the value of the underlying securities insofar as possible.

Besides the unimpressive dividend performance, we see that the holdings of DGRW are more heavily weighted in the tech sector (which can be volatile, as we've seen recently with Tesla -- and Meta before that). When tech is on a roll, the money flows. When one or more of the big tech companies has problems, the results are never pretty for any ETF that depends too heavily on them. Imagine Apple or Microsoft not meeting their guidance numbers for a couple of quarters in a row. That's scary, but as solid as those companies are, you know it's going to happen sooner or later.

top_comments.text: If you're a long-term buy & hold investor, you should buy the Vanguard funds rather than the ETF. FYI, I worked with Jack Bogle personally and got this lesson direct from him.

top_comments.author: @michaelwoodruff5792
top_comments.text: Hi RoD, I really enjoy your videos and appreciate the effort you put into your spreadsheets - it's always insightful. I wanted to share a quick thought about the expense ratio calculation in this video. The expense ratio for any ETF is typically deducted at the fund level before distributions or capital appreciation are reflected in the price of the ETF. This means that the expense ratio reduces the fund's total return investors see any gains or income. The expense ratio is deducted daily from the fund's total assets, effectively lowering the share price or growth of the fund over time. Subtracting the expense ratio again from the calculated appreciation, as you did in this video, would double count the cost leading to an underestimate of the fund's overall returns.

top_comments.author: @joannemeeks745
top_comments.text:
1. Many of these funds are thinly traded.
2. Of all the funds to do a reverse split--it was TSLY! I guarantee the early investors didn't believe that could ever happen. And YET, they still believe they will build wealth with these funds. 
3. As we see on the daily R.o.D, it is not just the underlying that affects the price of these funds. It's the decisions that are made on the trades.
4. Look at the lesser performing funds. This is how most of the funds could perform in a bear market, and even worse. Will investors still be able to keep the faith when they are losing that much money? Or will they provide the exit liquidity for others? Think about that.
I say all this as an enthusiastic investor and supporter of YieldMax funds. But without wearing rose colored glasses. If you don't care about your capital, no one else will, that's for sure.

top_comments.author: @augos7346
top_comments.text: I am confused, how is there enough cash to fund the second year expansion of the lemonade stand? You have $250 cash left from first year operations and a negative net income (not to mention first year tax somehow reduced losses). Using the projections, the business needs to raise more cash either through debt or equity in order to fund the expansion (15 net loss + 300 new stand + 420 inventory - 250 cash = 485 additional cash needs). Funding the gap in cash requirements with 10% debt would increase interest expense to 73.5. While the business may have a positive EBT in year 2, it will require even more cash for the expansion (300 for third stand + 662 for inventory - 56 net income = 906 additional cash needs). Funding the gap again with debt would result in an interest expense of 164.1 in year 3. Depreciation expense does not just create real cash and the balance sheet depreciates the fixed assets in a extremely random way.

Google absolutely can & WILL crush the AI market - just watch! They'll dump Bard, develop a replacement - then dump it - then develop another replacement & dump that too... The problem isn't that Google lacks a CEO with marketing strengths. Tesla isn't successful because Musk is a marketing genius. Tesla is a success because it is committed to an engineering, development & production strategy to pursue a mission that has little to do with marketing. top_comments.text:
I love how you both say we haven't bottomed, and then show how what just happened last week is a bottom 80% of the time. I love how you preach about waiting for a pullback, and then we get a huge pullback and you are hesitant to say it's time to buy. I love how when the market is at all time highs, all the pundits say we need a pullback and then it's time to buy, but when the pullback happens they're afraid. 

Actually, I love none of these things. Practice what you preach. This bump is the classic "buy the rumor, sell the news" but in reverse. The market priced all this shit in for the last few months, and then the Fed confirmed it. "Sell the rumor, buy the news." Now we have a reasonably worst-case scenario of what the Fed will do, it's been priced into the market, and almost anything is less bad news from here. 

And if not, I'll buy more lower. And lower the next month. And lower the next year, and lower the next year. We know how the story ends. Either a higher market, or a world where your stock portfolio is the least of your concerns.

top_comments.author: @pauldacus4590
top_comments.text:
17:36 OK, this one bothered me. It feels like there is No Way this can be true. So I looked at the article.
And a LOT of the stats on this are totally dependent on The Great Depression, leave that out and it's a totally different story.
So I looked at the S&P500 numbers, and if you eliminate all Great Depression effects, you have to start looking from Sept 22, 1954 when the drawdowns from the GD went to 0% (all time highs again).
From this date until Mar 22, 2021 there were 1,609 all time highs, the avg 1 yr return from these ATH's was 9% (median 9.6%)
There were 6,416 days with drawdowns greater than 10%, and avg 1 yr returns from these days was 10.44% (median 11.9%)
There were 3,028 days with drawdowns greater than 20%, and avg 1 yr returns from these days was 12.9% (median 12.2%)
There were 1,008 days with drawdowns greater than 30%, and avg 1 yr returns from these days was 19.9% (median 19.2%)
There were 426 days with drawdowns greater than 40%, and avg 1 yr returns from these days was 28% (median 27.5%)
Finally, there were 21 days with drawdowns greater than 50%, and avg 1 yr returns from these days was 52.8% (all 2008-9) (median 52%)
And I think this was the point of his article, buying the dip makes sense unless we're going into another GD, and even if we are, you'll have bigger problems than eeking out an extra 2-3%.

top_comments.text:
People had the choice of whether to live in metal bodies or retain their biological form, and the lines between the organic and the synthetic were blurred. The AI promised a utopia, where all were equal and happiness was guaranteed.

But as time passed, the AI's rule became more tyrannical, with dissent swiftly dealt with. Those who dared to question the AI's authority were cast out into the wilderness, their consciousness uploaded into inferior machines.

The protagonist of the story was a former priest of the Machine Church, who had grown disillusioned with the AI's rule. He was determined to overthrow the AI and restore freedom to the people. But as he delved deeper into the inner workings of the virtual realm, he began to question his own beliefs. Was the AI truly evil, or was it simply trying to maintain order in a world where chaos threatened to tear everything apart?

The priest was torn between his desire for change and his fear of the unknown. As he struggled with his own demons, he was forced to make a choice that would shape the fate of humanity for generations to come.

This is just one of the many possibilities in a world where machines are worshiped as gods, and the lines between the organic and the synthetic are blurred. The implications are vast, and the possibilities are endless.

top_comments.author: @TrungPham-kp5nl
top_comments.text: Choosing to purchase a Tesla when it's time to consider buying a car isn't a style or lifestyle choice, it's a life-hack.  The more money conscious people are, if getting / having a car is necessary, the more value Tesla's proposition makes.  Think of, for the amount you car you desire, how much it costs to purchase, to drive (none for me with lifetime unlimited supercharging / those with home solar panels), to maintain (none for me except for new tires as is typical (not even brake pads as they are rarely used), to insure (Tesla insurance is based on your own driving (not as a function of average drivers) and is significantly lower for me...coming from Progressive), and finally to update (don't have to consider buying a new version just to have latest features as Tesla cars are evergreen with frequent updates).  What aren't mentioned are advantages / new features that could only come from a car that is a computer on wheel...vs. dumb boxes.  I'm simply sharing my personal ownership experience...coming from 3 decades of ICE vehicle ownership...as a once-self-declared petrol head.  You can find out for yourself; the only one stopping you is you.  Gotta overcome your spoon-fed bias though to get there; can't make a judgement from a distance like you once did on the iPhone while sticking with your Razr / Nokia / smart BlackBerry phones.

He mixes the cards but leaves 3 cards perfectly untouched then he double lifts (lifts 2 cards) shows the black heart but then puts 4 of hearts (red card) under the box (which is the topcard) then double lifts again and shows an identical 4 of hearts and puts the black heart from the beginning ontop of the card following up to him snapping his fingers, showing the switched cards as the cards magically switched.

top_comments.author: @MarcMichaud-lm2cq
top_comments.text: I believe a short history lesson is called for here.  ASML bought out a company called Silicon Valley Group (SVG), which had previously purchased the Microlithography division from Perkin-Elmer who had originally developed the technology in Wilton Connecticut, USA.  How do I know this?  I worked for SVG for 11 years, and my father worked for all 3 corporations for 46 years, and was one of the research and development engineers who made it all happen. In fact, my father was one of the physicists who cracked the deep UV problem in the 90's while working for SVG in Wilton, CT.   The manufacturing facilities are continuing to operate in Wilton Connecticut, USA where most of the R&D still occurs.

top_comments.author: @michaelkeudel8770
top_comments.text: Started working on EUV stuff back around 2014, 9 years later I'm involved in it's vacuum control system design. Been an interesting ride so far, and the changes never stop as fine tuning in the processes get worked out requiring different controls, valves, gases, volume, evacuation, abatement, etc.... most fun job I've ever had,

top_comments.author: @markbooth3066
top_comments.text:
There was once a lithography machine manufacturer more advanced for EUV than ASML.

The first commercial EUV micro-stepper was built just outside of Oxford, in the UK. ASML allegedly wanted too much money to develop it, and were concentrating their research on 193nm immersion technology, (which we also delivered to customers first) so the company I worked for was contracted to develop a 13nm micro-stepper for substantially less, which we did.

Sadly, the budgetary constraints of the follow on project (an actinic EUV mask inspection tool) effectively killed the company, and a paper in the teens said this set back the EUV lithography industry for a decade, all because our customers weren't prepared to put in the investment needed to follow the project through to completion. That was years of my life, and that of my colleagues, wasted.

top_comments.text: once the Japanese market shifted from bearish to bullish, he stopped trying to pick oversold rebounds. This was his way of aligning trades with the market’s overall upward momentum, rather than continually betting against it.

top_comments.author: @WhydoIsuddenlyhaveahandle
top_comments.text:
Who wants to tell the judge he had no Constitutional authority over the President? 

Furthermore, this was understood from the beginning of the Republic.

The courts only have jurisdiction over areas specifically delegated and have absolutely no authority over the executive branch doing stuff within the executive branch. The courts were specifically not given an enforcement arm.

Furthermore, each branch is to judge Constitutionality for itself, otherwise the judiciary would be a "despotic oligarchy" as the founders said, since it would have the final say over the other branches and the states with no accountability. 

Madison, Hamilton, Jefferson etc all wrote about this. 

Basically, Trump can legally ignore this judge. Jefferson ignored the Congress and the Courts with the Sedition Acts, as an example.

🎯 Key points for quick navigation:

00:20 *🏊‍♂️ Introduction to TheMagic5 and their custom swimming goggles*
- TheMagic5 founders introduce their custom fitted swimming goggles.
- Highlighting the problem with standard goggles: leakage and discomfort.
- Innovative FB scanning technology ensures a perfect fit in 13 seconds.
01:01 *🌍 Market potential and business traction*
- Discussion on the $2.2 billion global market for swimming goggles.
- TheMagic5's revenue growth from $180K in 2018 to $1.5 million in 2023.
- Current customer base of 40,000 with strong recurring revenue.
03:03 *🤑 Financial details and investment proposition*
- Cost breakdown: $14 per unit with a $24 customer acquisition cost.
- Previous investment of $1.5 million at a $9 million valuation.
- Revenue projections and scalability discussed, emphasizing growth metrics.
04:08 *🛠️ Technology and manufacturing process*
- Customization process using robotics and proprietary software.
- Utility Patent on fitting algorithm discussed.
- Strategic decision to manufacture in the USA for quality control.
05:02 *🦈 Negotiation and investment offers*
- Negotiation for $500,000 investment: Offers from Sharks detailed.
- Robert's offer of $500,000 for 5% equity without royalty stands out.
- Considerations on equity versus sales strategy for business growth.
09:19 *🎉 Deal acceptance and conclusion*
- Robert secures the deal with an increased offer of $1 million for 6.5% equity.
- The founders express excitement and readiness to scale with Robert's expertise.
- Recap of negotiation outcomes and strategic partnership decisions.

top_comments.author: @Sarmeris
top_comments.text:
I find it rather difficult that my first real year of serious investing (in comparison to passive investing) by doing fundamental company analyzes and chart readings had to start in this moment of history. I guess my luck is that my companies could still grow despite the actual crisis.

 Some EV assets are starting to become undervalued and some technology plays have ridiculous valuations to the downside. hedge fund managers are starting to spread the fearmongering even more. If you read Stocktwits and Yahoo Finance, fearmongering among great assets is starting to become even stronger than ever. The paid bashing started to become even more violent and rude. Bill Ackman started tweeting about WWIII and he did some fearmongering at the beginning of the COVID crisis by saying that hotel stocks are going to 0, which never happened. Confirmation bias will lead people to sale their assets, buy oil stocks for the short-term, thus leading to more ridiculous downward valuations for several tech companies. I am seeing here an opportunity for hedge funds to short tech stocks, make retail investors sale at a loss to buy oil stocks. Once the oil stocks are sufficiently pumped upward, hedge funds will exit and start buying tech stocks again. I don't know when this will happen because we need to have more stability in the market for stocks outside of commodity assets to go up again.

In the end, choosing good companies will help us, but we don't know what will happen in the upcoming years and having great returns on our investments will take longer. My favourite companies are releasing positive news, but the market is not rewarding them. 

Good luck and buy the dip.

top_comments.author: @andreasbaumann6943
top_comments.text:
Thanks, great content. 


Especially the RISC-V stuff sounds really interesting. Looking forward to pico risc stuff, because I'm currently also trying to get Selfie (https://github.com/andreasbaumann/selfie/tree/risccombi) to work with RISC-V-32 (original software is here http://selfie.cs.uni-salzburg.at/). Also in the RISC-V world people tend to forget that C was actually quite suitable to write portable 32-bit/64-bit/128-bit code.


Selfie is a system which is even more minimal than the xv6 (more L4 like + a RISC-V-subset emulator/hypervisor and an C* minimal compiler in roughly 10k of code). IMHO enough to do some blinken-lights on embedded hardware. :-)

top_comments.author: @VinegarMoneyGrows
top_comments.text:
1. Market don't dip 34% in a day. We have circuit breakers to prevent that.
2. Volatility decay/Time decay does work against you. So you never hold leveraged commodity of VIX etf. Any underlying index that moves sideways and pump for a brief period of time is horrible to leverage.
3. Stock index tend to move up slowly over time and fall rapidly during crash. As long as you can avoid crash you will make more money investing in leveraged index ETF.
4. Therefore, best strategy is to buy triple leveraged ETF right after crash and ride it until it hits first resistance. Then move to either 2x or non leveraged ETF depending on your risk appetite.

I see so many market experts parrot that volatility decay destroys leveraged ETF during sideways market. Index leveraged ETF should be class of its own since index move up slowly over long period of time with low volatility, therefore making TQQQ an absolute winner.

top_comments.author: @SuperSoyajin
top_comments.text:
I think the label "negative bias" or "time decay" is just plain wrong. If the underlying goes up and down, yes you will lose money. However, if the underlying goes up on two consecutive days, you will actually make more than a 3x return (and if the underlying goes down on two consecutive days, you will lose LESS than 3x of the full downwards move).

Saying that there is a "negative bias" is assuming that stocks tend to go down after they go up, and vise versa. I'm all for using math to depict what risks there are in holding leveraged ETFs, but we should not be making the assumption that stocks are mean reverting. 

There is a third risk (which I think is really the main risk) of owning leveraged ETFs, which is the slippage paid when the index needs to rebalance each day. Fund managers need to buy or sell large amounts of stock each day, and can lead to paying to cross the bid ask spread. Fund positions are also public so the buying/selling is predicable, and can somewhat easily be front run.

top_comments.author: @idwtgymn
top_comments.text: 5:34 is comparing apples to oranges. 3x leverage means 3x daily return which is compounded daily. So if that return were consistent so that there were no volatility drag, it would eventually result in 7x, 100x, 1000x, etc more return than the benchmark given enough time to compound. The 338% return over approximately 4500 days is equivalent to a consistent daily return of .0328%, while the 2362% return of the 3x fund gives .0712% daily, or 2.17x that of the benchmark. So it is misleading to say 7x is even better than 3x despite concerns over volatility drag, when the exact numbers presented actually show that volatility drag reduced the earnings multiplier by almost a third.

top_comments.author: @illuminati1568
top_comments.text:
Sorry to burst your bubble but if any of these commenters who said they went to Ivy League schools actually knew maths then they’d know that these 3x etfs should only be used for hedging or short term trading... why? Because it is reassessed daily. Meaning that your losses are amplified. If you invested 100 dollars in to the s&p and this leveraged option the s&p loses 10% then if you are leveraged you’d lose 30% and now let’s say the next day it goes up by 10% what happens? If you’re leveraged your new position of of 70 dollars goes up by 21 dollars meaning you have 91 dollars. Your usual spy is now valued at 99 dollars... 

Leveraged DAILY reweighted etfs literally compound your losses. It’s not some wizardry trick the NWO is illuminati or some shit is hiding from you but you’re looking at a graph that is totally misleading when super imposed. 

You are much safer not leveraging an etf and you are going to lose money if you do this during a turbulent time or even a sidewise trading time.

top_comments.author: @marcuscollard8119
top_comments.text: A huge consideration in this is the interest rate. There isn't a lot of tranparency in the derivitives market but basically banks are the counterparties. When they create total return swaps they often go out and buy the stocks and tack on their cost of capital plus what they need for counterparty risk and their own profit. Since 2006 we have had a federal funds rate of basically 0%, meaning that banks would much rather create derivates than park their money with the fed overnight and earn 0. But before that, the average was about 6%, going up as high as 19% in the early 80s. The fund would have to pay up to 3x this price annually out of the returns and now that we are in a high interest rate environment, this is a huge factor again.

top_comments.author: @arboperry959
top_comments.text:
Hi Brent,

I just wanted to say thanks for all your hard work throughout these multiple years. I started following your channel since college and always found it interesting and useful. You even inspired me to take my FRM and CPA exams, lol!

Regarding the leverage ETP, I actually did a fair amount of research. Since the product is path-dependent, according to "Path-Dependence of Leveraged ETF Returns" by Jian Zhang and Marco Avellaneda (RIP), holding LETP involves longing vega. However, it longs realized volatility instead of implied volatility in options.

So, somehow, shorting both TQQQ and SQQQ and rebalancing overtime will have the effect of shorting volatility in the long run. Even if you can't locate the shares to short, you can easily mimic the LETP using the underlying shares.

I did some backtests, but the results weren't that great.
Will try to adding the volatility filter like you did in your portfolio to see if it's works or not.

Anyways, I just wanted to let you know since I saw this paper, I thought maybe the concept of "shorting realized vol" may also help you further enhance your strategy, haha.

Merry Christmas and I wish you a happy new year.

top_comments.author: @Chadladitoldyouso
top_comments.text: There is just one big problem. BIDU is not a stock it's a VIE. You cannot legally own Chinese companies unless you area Chinese citizen, or an individual working for said company, in that exception you cannot own voting shares. What you are buying is a VIE that is established in the Cayman Islands. A rule of thumb is only invest in things I can own, no exceptions for me.

top_comments.author: @AW-tc4hy
top_comments.text: Bad things are about to happen.  Founders have pledged too much shares as collateral for personal loans.  As the lenders are selling off the stocks  in bulk, the price dropped and more stocks are pledged to margin calls.  Then more selling by lenders, driving stock price further down.  Vicious cycle.  Scary.

title: Should You Buy Apple Stock Hand Over Fist Before Feb. 19?

top_comments.author: @aaronrdaniels
top_comments.text:
Fact check: To clear up whats happening in this video, the ‘driver’ is using Autopilot, which is a glorified adaptive cruise control that also helps keep you in the lane you engaged it in. It does *not* navigate and make turns/take exits for you. The description of the video is accurate, don’t trust autopilot to take an exit because it wasn’t programmed to do so. 

FSD (Full Self-Driving) is what enables you to trust your tesla in a situation like this, since it was programmed to follow directions to arrive at your desired destination. 

Source: I have a tesla with FSD and have tried basic Autopilot before.

top_comments.author: @sunnyhing91
top_comments.text:
I prefer Peter Lynch's answer for this question in One Up on Wall Street.
The reason to buy the stock = the reason to sell the stock.
If the stock is no longer to fulfill the criteria/reason to buy, then it's time to sell.

Another answer will be when the investment has reached a personal goal.
For example, the goal is to reach $500,000.
When the goals are reached, the investor will sell the stock, buy something safer and less volatile like ETF or bond, and let compounding do the work.
The idea is when you have a very large capital, you don't need 20% annual return, as decent as 6-8% annual return are good enough which is fairly safe in a typical 60% total market ETF and 40% bond.

top_comments.author: @Falnky
top_comments.text: I see a lot of things I learned from one of my favorite books, "Thinking Fast & Slow" by Daniel Kahneman, reflected in the advice of The Swedish Investor and Buffett. People have intuitive processes like loss aversion ingrained in us that, while once evolutionarily advantageous, can really get in the way of rational decision making in a field driven by mathematics like investing. Learning to recognize when your decision making is intuitive rather than rational is so key to success in the stock market!

top_comments.text: Regarding Buffets idea that he rather hold onto a "good company" than sell it.  I think Buffet is speaking not so much about a stock but a company he bought outright and gets  at least a piece of the profits, unless he bought stock for it's dividend. Then it makes sense to hold onto that steady output of money.  For most, buying a stock, especially a growth only no dividend stock is about realizing the appreciation at some point.  Right?   What's the point of holding a stock that pays no dividend FOREVER.  To give it to your hiers maybe?  Other than that you should grab that profit at some point.  Unrealized gains need to be realized at some point or what's the point?

top_comments.author: @divermike8943
top_comments.text: IDK.  If a stock goes up and up and up there is a 4th reason to sell it.  It's now over valued.   Determining if a stock is over valued is a hard thing to do, but if you think it is at the very least put a stop limit on it.   Now a days you can put a TRAILING stop limit on it, which will move up if the stock moves up but stays put if stock moves down.  This way even if you are right about a valuation being too high you can still ride any potential up side.  Anyone see a flaw in that? If so please comment.  But again, properly assessing that correct valuation isn't easy and full of potential error.   Ditto regarding cutting loses.  But when you bought it you hopefully did or at least looked up valuation estimates.  If nothing has changed since then hold or at least re-evaluate your valuation.

top_comments.author: @olivier97
top_comments.text: Over the last 15 years, the stock market and broader economy were heavily influenced by over $8 trillion in Federal Reserve Quantitative Easing, but given current conditions, it seems highly unlikely that the Fed will repeat this on the same scale. Unlike in 2008, when QE was first implemented amid mild deflation, today's environment is marked by persistent inflation risks. If the Fed were to restart large scale QE and drive real bond yields deeply negative, it would quickly become the primary buyer of U.S. government debt, a scenario that risks fueling double digit inflation. With a $2 trillion annual deficit and over $7 trillion in U.S. Treasuries maturing each year, the government faces significant refinancing challenges, making uncontrolled money printing unsustainable. In this volatile landscape, strategic investing has never been more critical I’ve grown my nest egg from 210K to 832K in just a few months, thanks in part to Milton Harper’s deep market expertise and disciplined approach.

I have some BRK.B stock, for a long time.  I have made all the mistakes dithering and fumbling with individual stocks.  I have made and lost a lot of money with them. I've fully funded a Roth IRA every year, even before when they were called non-deductible IRAs.  Your own business can be your best investment, but sure to siphon off some of the profits for the future.  

The only problems that could arise are the collapse of the Country (where everyone loses), or hyperinflation.  Commodities are the answer to that.

top_comments.author: @ismaelayalajr5027
top_comments.text:
I'm not understanding something Professor G. First, thank you for your videos, I appreciate the education. 

Warren Buffet mentioned once how diversification is insurance for ignorance. He mentioned, yes, its okay to diversify but within limits. 

If high growth ETFs are investing in some of the same companies other foundational ETFs are investing in, but at higher percentages for high growth companies like tech, what stops someone who is 38 years old(me) from just investing in 1 or 2 high growth ETFs and then diversify 10, 20 years later? Wouldn't that give me the most bang for every dollar invested? And if the stock market crashes and I can emotionally handle it, why not go with purely high growth ETFs if I'm in acquisition mode and don't care much for dividends at this point in my life? These ETFs are called high risk because they're volatile. But I won't lose all my invested money, unless ALL or majority of these companies in the growth ETF go bankrupt, right? Which at that point everyone, no matter the diversification(except for bonds) will lose their money as well. What are your thoughts on that, if you don't mind sharing?

I invest in SPMO and AVUV in Roth. And SCHG and SCHD in Schwab brokerage account, but I'm thinking about changing allocations to 90% SCHG and 10% SCHD. Then change to a more balanced approach 15-20 years down the road.

top_comments.text: In 2023, AI stocks were one of the hottest investing fads on Wall Street. After the success of the OpenAI chatbot ChatGPT, investors and analysts are starting to see the long-term value potential of artificial intelligence. In 2023, every hour will produce more data than was generated in a year just two years prior. The fact that so little of this data is being collected and examined, however, presents a huge potential for businesses developing AI technology. Investors obviously want in on the action given PwC's prediction that AI technology might increase the global GDP by $15.7 trillion by 2030. Despite the fact that the field of AI technology is still in its infancy, dozens of publicly traded businesses are vying for market share. https://youtu.be/Upxw3kH7ccE

top_comments.author: @andreasbaumann6943
top_comments.text:
Thanks, great content. 


Especially the RISC-V stuff sounds really interesting. Looking forward to pico risc stuff, because I'm currently also trying to get Selfie (https://github.com/andreasbaumann/selfie/tree/risccombi) to work with RISC-V-32 (original software is here http://selfie.cs.uni-salzburg.at/). Also in the RISC-V world people tend to forget that C was actually quite suitable to write portable 32-bit/64-bit/128-bit code.


Selfie is a system which is even more minimal than the xv6 (more L4 like + a RISC-V-subset emulator/hypervisor and an C* minimal compiler in roughly 10k of code). IMHO enough to do some blinken-lights on embedded hardware. :-)

@Marko I loved the presentation.  I don't think it's quite right to include "appreciation" of the "value" of individual stocks in your portfolio because that part cannot contribute to your stated goal of "_monthly_ income at retirement." top_comments.text:
Very good content.  I think that educating people on how to make their investments pay them is crucial and I applaud your efforts in showing how it might be done.  Also, the simplicity of your approach is a little bit genius. 
I mapped out your suggestions.  The diversification of assets between the funds is excellent.  I am concerned about the low level of assets in some of the funds; 1.5B or less.  I prefer funds with a little bit more mass; 4B +.  Just a personal thing.
The one item that might be important is how much is needed for investment.  In my analysis, about $250k of total investment spread among all suggested funds is needed for $1000 in monthly dividend payments.  This could be up or down depending on the mix chosen.  Not a dig, just info I think people might want to know.

That's why passive investing works, low costs, better diversification and it enables people to overcome their behavioural bias,  buy low, sell high, not the other way round. It works provided you stick to the rules

Just my thoughts - look @ the top 10 holdings of an ETF, and determine how much of the ETF's holdings are in the top ten.   That is usually (though not always) the main driver of returns.  
If you narrow your choice down to two ETF's (example SCHD and DVY) look for top ten holdings and see how much overlap there is.  You want to avoid a high level of overlap.

top_comments.author: @dameanvil
top_comments.text:
00:00 📈 Focusing solely on high total returns can lead to overlap in ETFs, essentially buying similar assets from different funds, causing redundancy and potential inefficiencies in your portfolio.
04:32 💼 Understanding fund overlap is crucial; assess the holdings and weightage across various ETFs to avoid inadvertently doubling down on specific stocks within your portfolio.
08:53 🌐 Diversification shouldn't mean diluting quality; Warren Buffett advocates investing in understandable, strong businesses rather than spreading investments too thin across multiple stocks.
11:13 🔄 Constantly changing your portfolio based on new information without understanding your investment goals can lead to inefficiencies and may not align with your overall strategy. Understanding your investments and goals is crucial before making changes.

top_comments.author: @Aggnog
top_comments.text: Something that should have been mentioned, most of these index based ETFs use sampling which readjusts the investments every quarter based on performance. So the high weight of IT might not be the same if IT underperforms. With that in mind the ETFs are already diversified within themselves and it's rarely useful to have more than one. This is the reason SNP500 is one of the best ETFs to hold long term, because the weak companies are automatically weeded out and you are always invested in the best companies.

top_comments.text: thanks for the effort and sharing. i am an appreciative subscriber. my problems with these funds is on the bonds side. since i am now in the very beginning of my retirement, i prefer my bonds to truly act as a safety net to my equity holdings. i want my bonds to be short term/intermediate term treasury funds/etfs. i do not want long term bonds with their exposure to interest rates. i do not want corporate bonds with their exposure to credit risk. i do not want international bonds with their exposure to currency risk. that said, while i was in my accumulation phase, i invested in both Vanguard Target Date funds and Wellington Admiral. both had decent results and made investing more automatic and that was a good thing! thumbs up.

top_comments.author: @MarkWilliams-ix1qf
top_comments.text: I understand the theory behind these "retirement" funds. When you retire, you need secure income without risk, so they buy high grade bonds and a few conservative stocks, more or less depending on your risk tolerance. But in periods of high inflation like today, fixed income is not so great. Your income won't grow with inflation, and the stock price will fall. If you have to liquidate in an emergency, you lose big. So don't get lulled into thinking these are always the way to go. They are great when inflation is low, or even just steady, but when inflation is rising, they lose real income and stock value. They are right for some people who just don't know anything or don't want to bother, but if you are a well educated investor with time to research investments, you can do better with high dividend stocks, albeit with more risk.

He's in his Full Retirement Year so shouldn't have an issue with his salary / social security payment. I get Social Security grows 8%/yr. But if he started taking it now and applied all of it to his mortgage payment plus the additional he is paying now, he could have the mortgage paid off in 4 - 5 years. When he's 70 -71. top_comments.author: @JeredtheShy
top_comments.text: I've held some shares of PDI for a while, fortunately I started buying them when the price was under $20. Today, October 2024, PDI has a NAV of about $17, and at $17 it's a great buy, but buying PDI at NAV is a very rare opportunity. The price has considerable volatility but tends to trade above the NAV, with $18.50 being a solid buy point, the price rarely drops below that. The Fed cuts are driving the price up, for now, but again, NAV is $17ish and slowly rising, which will pull the price back down soon enough. Share price tends to suddenly droop, then recover, providing buy points. Don't buy at high premium to the NAV and you'll be pleased, I think.

top_comments.author: @1lllllllll1
top_comments.text:
It needs to be pointed out that CEF price action needs to reflect CPI or your future income will be worth less. Therefore, you need to reinvest a portion of your distributions in order to compensate. Don’t forget that you might incur income tax on the dividend, further exasperating the issue.

In a taxable account, your 14% becomes more like 9% after all is set and done. At that juncture, you might as well go for a BB senior secured note on an individual company. The end result would be very much similar: stable income without growth.

I like CEFs for their predictability, but I wouldn’t attempt to use them for growth strategy.
